body:
<!-- This form is for bug reports and feature requests ONLY!

If you're looking for help check [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/kubernetes) and the [troubleshooting guide](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug-application-cluster/troubleshooting/).

If the matter is security related, please disclose it privately via https://kubernetes.io/security/.
-->

**Is this a BUG REPORT or FEATURE REQUEST?**:

/kind bug
/sig network
/area ipvs
/area ipv6

**What happened**:

`kube-proxy` with IPVS mode creates a `kube-ipvs0` interface for binding service IPs.

```
ip addr show kube-ipvs0
5: kube-ipvs0: <BROADCAST,NOARP,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN group default 
    link/ether 1a:ab:99:c0:a2:0d brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
    inet 10.3.0.10/32 brd 10.3.0.10 scope global kube-ipvs0
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
    inet 10.3.0.1/32 brd 10.3.0.1 scope global kube-ipvs0
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
    inet6 fe80::18ab:99ff:fec0:a20d/64 scope link 
       valid_lft forever preferred_lft forever
```

kube-proxy periodically [tries to unbind](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/v1.12.1/pkg/proxy/ipvs/proxier.go#L1583) addresses it doesn't know about from the interface. It tries to unbind the IPv6 address over and over.

```
Failed to unbind service addr fe80::18ab:99ff:fec0:a20d from dummy interface kube-ipvs0: error unbind address: fe80::18ab:99ff:fec0:a20d from interface: kube-ipvs0, err: cannot assign requested address
```

The error is a little vague, but see below. The IP parsing or address deletion code [here](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/v1.12.1/pkg/proxy/ipvs/netlink_linux.go#L61) may be a suspect.

**What you expected to happen**:

Either ignore the IPv6 address on the interface (its not hurting anything) or remove it correctly. 

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:

Its perfectly natural for a new interface to have an inet6 address by default.

```
sudo ip link add name eth99 type dummy
```

If for some reason your `kube-ipvs0` interface doesn't have a similar address, you can add one to repro.

```
sudo ip addr add fe80::4482:f7ff:fe36:3e6d/64 dev kube-ipvs0
```

**Anything else we need to know?**:

**Environment**:
- Kubernetes version (use `kubectl version`): v1.12.1
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: AWS, GCP, DigitalOcean, bare-metal, Azure
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Container Linux 1855.4.0
- Kernel (e.g. `uname -a`): 4.14.67-coreos
- Install tools: Typhoon

labels.description: Categorizes issue or PR as related to a bug.
labels.name: kind/bug

labels.description: Categorizes an issue or PR as relevant to SIG Network.
labels.name: sig/network

title: kube-proxy IPVS spurious logs removing IPv6 address
